comments.body: Does it mean that there is no error even if internal mapper is set?
no, it means we tolerate a second call to `Unstructured()`

The fix works only because two calls do NOT share the same Builder as previous (changes in `describe.go`).

I think the change in `builder.go` is unnecessary and it changes current behavior.

You can assume that the first call set `b.mapper = b.unstructured`, so if using the same builder the second call will meet the condition and get the error.
just an internal map key

why does Unstructured affect isLocal? whether or not you make use of conversion or typed objects depends on the typer/convertor you give to the builder, not whether it has a server connection and can look up restmappings, right?

> why does Unstructured affect isLocal? whether or not you make use of conversion or typed objects depends on the typer/convertor you give to the builder, not whether it has a server connection and can look up restmappings, right?

It's the point where the mapper is chosen and the old spot can logically wire this piece of information.  A few more pulls and the mapper won't be specified by callers and this will effectively drop out.

> doc this means the returned Info will not have a RESTMapping or Client set

That's already doc'ed on the mapping and client fields
not seeing that doc, but fine to include in follow up cleanup pulls. also, the doc on the Object field is drifting, should update once this is in it's final shape.

@deads2k thanks, comments addressed. However the `b.mapper.RESTMapping` here and in line 612 will return a "not matched" error if only the kind is given: `$ kubectl get Kind`.

The following will work:
```
$ kubectl get Kind.group.com/resource_name
$ kubectl get Kind.group.com
```

> $ kubectl get Kind.group.com/resource

This string makes no sense.  Try explaining again.  is "resource" actually a "resourcename"?

> This string makes no sense. Try explaining again. is "resource" actually a "resourcename"?

Yes, edited my previous comment's example to reflect this better. It should have been `Kind.group.com/resource_name`

This is not correct code.  We were always accepting resource before first here.  Checking for kind first causes an invalidation of the discovery cache on *every* CLI call, which is a huge usability regression.

This chunk either needs to be reverted, or KindFor() must be checked first.
This is must fix for 1.10 because of the regression.
Thanks, this is addressed by https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/60932
What if fieldSelector is not nil?  What happens then?

> What if fieldSelector is not nil? What happens then?

This does not affect `fieldSelector`. Will work as expected.

comments.body: This is not the right place to check this.  Local and unstructured have nothing to do with each other.  Local commands should absolutely be able to function without needing to have compiled in objects.
@smarterclayton Thanks, will make a patch to address this
Why check if b.errs is empty?

> Why check if b.errs is empty?

If the path cannot be accessed, b.paths is empty. I think file extension is not the reason, we do not need to return the message.
I don't think this change made the method more readable.
I don't want every exit to declare the whole struct though.  I think that's not a consistent pattern.
This never mutates.  Again, I find the value questionable in a method this size.
I'm not sure what you're arguing for.  I don't want each line to have 40 characters that are exactly the same that someone will cut and paste incorrectly.

> I'm not sure what you're arguing for. I don't want each line to have 40 characters that are exactly the same that someone will cut and paste incorrectly.

I'd prefer a `.with` construct, but I won't stick on it.  There already be dragons here.
Is args the list of args to the sub command?  Or the full list of args?
They're only the set passed to the sub command (in `kubectl get all`, `[all]` would be the args slice)

This check is somewhat misleading. In resource/builder.go, the call to `ReplaceAliases` replaces `all` with all supported resources [1], and then `ResourceTypeOrNameArgs` will split it into a slice of string [2]

1.`pods,replicationcontrollers,services,statefulsets,horizontalpodautoscalers,jobs,deployments,replicasets`
2.`[]string{"pods,replicationcontrollers,services,statefulsets,horizontalpodautoscalers,jobs,deployments,replicasets"}`

This means that `all` won't be passed in as `args[0]`.

The unit test needs to be updated as well.

> This check is somewhat misleading. In resource/builder.go, the call to ReplaceAliases replaces all with all supported resources [1], and then ResourceTypeOrNameArgs will split it into a slice of string [2]
> This means that all won't be passed in as args[0].

Although `all` will never be `args[0]` if the args slice that is passed to `MultipleTypesRequested` is built from the output of `replaceAliases` or `SplitResourceArgument`, this check is mostly for cases such as https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/kubectl/cmd/get.go#L424, where arguments from a sub command are passed to it, without first going through other functions in resource/builder.go

> this check is mostly for cases such as https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/kubectl/cmd/get.go#L424

Did you mean this line? (line number was changed since the link points to `master`):

```go
if resource.MultipleTypesRequested(args) || cmdutil.MustPrintWithKinds(objs, infos, sorter) {
```

IIUC, before this line, we make a call to `ResourceTypeOrNameArgs`:

```go 
	r := resource.NewBuilder(mapper, typer, resource.ClientMapperFunc(f.UnstructuredClientForMapping), unstructured.UnstructuredJSONScheme).
		NamespaceParam(cmdNamespace).DefaultNamespace().AllNamespaces(allNamespaces).
		FilenameParam(enforceNamespace, &options.FilenameOptions).
		SelectorParam(selector).
		ExportParam(export).
		ResourceTypeOrNameArgs(true, args...).
		ContinueOnError().
		Latest().
		Flatten().
		Do()
```

After this call, `args` has been changed (aliases, including `all`, are expanded). Would you explain more on when the following situation would happen? 
> arguments from a sub command are passed to it, without first going through other functions in resource/builder.go

@janetkuo 
> After this call, args has been changed (aliases, including all, are expanded).

Apologies, I see what you mean now. I had tested the values of `args` in a line located above the call to `ResourceTypeOrNameArgs` in [this PR](https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/39042#discussion_r96523358), and had not realized that its value is mutated by the time it is used in 
```go
if resource.MultipleTypesRequested(args) || cmdutil.MustPrintWithKinds(objs, infos, sorter) {
```

> Would you explain more on when the following situation would happen?
>>arguments from a sub command are passed to it, without first going through other functions in resource/builder.go

I realize now that, at least for the time being, `MultipleTypesRequested` will never receive `all` as one of its arguments, however a potential situation where it will is if a call to this helper is ever made before a call to `ReplaceAliases`.
I see. LGTM then
If `arg` contains "," then this is already > 1, isn't it? Is this check here because of something like `pods,pods`?

Unrelated note, we need to think of a better structure for aliases. This and a number places will have issues once we add more aliases in addition to "all" (the only existing one ATM). Might be worth adding an issue.

@juanvallejo exactly, something along these lines. The important part is to have a structure to handle the configured aliases so we don't hardcode "all" everywhere, and it has to know if it maps to more than one kind. ;)

@caesarxuchao Because in the label command, it invokes RetrieveLatest function, which needs object's namespace, we should invoke SetNamespace before RetrieveLatest, otherwise it will return an error message ""no namespace set on resource %s %q""
Thank you @feihujiang. Sounds reasonable. RetrieveLatest is also used by other kubectl commands, why doesn't this cause problem for them?

@caesarxuchao Correct me if I'm wrong... I think it's because other commands don't use `FilenameParam()` and `Latest()` together. 

@feihujiang Can you add a comment like line 583 does?
@caesarxuchao yes, the answer @JanetKuo gived is my opinion.
Thank you both.
